block.p: The U.S. is moving to conform with recent rulings of GATT, which oversees world trade. The Bush Administration is seeking a more binding set of rules that it feels could help the U.S. in matters like foreign farm subsidies or piracy of American films and computer software. [ Page D1. ] The inaugural Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting was attended by 12 countries - the U.S., Japan, Canada, South Korea, New Zealand, Australia, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia and Brunei. [ D2. ]
Mexico is getting far less in new loans than it hoped for when it worked out a debt agreement in July. Because of this, bankers say some difficult, last-minute adjustments are likely. [ D1. ]

Belgian engineers hope to reopen the Benguela railroad, a link to Central Africa's mineral reserves that has been closed by civil war. The planned renovation reflects growing confidence in Angola's economic future. [ D12. ] The Economy

A plan to reduce acid rain by limiting pollutants from smokestacks of electric utility plants is drawing criticism from some of the cleanest utilities as well as the dirtiest. Utilities that burn natural gas and low-sulfur oil would have to cut pollution from existing plants if they want to build new ones, and oil-burning utilities say the bill does not recognize their pollution-control efforts. [ D2. ]
The changing nature of accounting and the workplace is leading to an array of conflict-of-interest problems for accountants and forcing them to make hard choices to keep clients. [ D1. ]

An F.B.I. inquiry into possible criminal charges against Charles H. Keating Jr. has been expanded to include his dealings with five Senators, officials say. Mr. Keating is the former head of Lincoln Savings in Irvine, Calif. [ A14. ] Companies
Resorts International is expected to announce a tentative agreement with bondholders today that will allow the company to reorganize. [ D1. ] The Media Business
Peter S. Kalikow wants to be remembered as the savior of the The New York Post. After 20 months, he says the tabloid newspaper has cost him about $80 million and some friendships. [ D1. ]
Car makers are taking creative risks with their advertising to break through the gridlock of car commercials. Spending for TV car advertising has more than doubled in five years. [ D13. ]
American TV producers are turning to foreign partners. The joint productions give Europeans more programming and help U.S. companies to share high costs. [ D13. ]

''Funny is money'' in the view of Home Box Office, which will introduce its Comedy Channel on Wednesday. But a battle is brewing with MTV, which is to introduce its own version - HA!, the TV Comedy Network - on April 1. Television. [ D13. ]

Kompass Intercontinental calls itself the first Soviet-American media company. The young concern has already won an agreement to revamp and publish a Soviet magazine devoted to classical music and dance and is scheduled to distribute the first issue of Moscow International Business. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D14. ] Today's Columns

Prosecutors insist that they will bring racketeering charges, even on Wall Street, when they see a pattern of corruption. New U.S. guidelines would restrict use of the RICO law in some instances, and six people convicted in one case received unexpectedly light sentences. Stephen Labaton: Business and the Law. [ D2. ]
Analysts say the positive view in the credit markets is likely to remain well into 1990, setting the stage for further reductions in interest rates. Credit Markets. [ D11. ]

Three New York banking companies have sold more than $1.6 billion of new stock in the last month, rebuilding capital depleted by huge losses incurred when they set aside reserves to cover third-world loans. Market Place. [ D10. ]
